scenarioDescription:
The HD 160691 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HD 160691 is a star with 1.08 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.38 times its radius. It is located 50.87 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 6.4 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

HD 160691 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HD 160691 system


HD 160691 b

HD 160691 b was discovered by the Anglo-Australian Telescope observatory, in 2001-07, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 1.50 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 160691 b is 532.968 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 160691 b is 13.500 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 160691 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


HD 160691 c

HD 160691 c was discovered by the Anglo-Australian Telescope observatory, in 2004-12, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 5.24 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 160691 c is 576.852 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 160691 c is 13.400 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 160691 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


HD 160691 d

HD 160691 d was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2004-10, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 160691 d is 10.561 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 160691 d is 3.240 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HD 160691 d is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


HD 160691 e

HD 160691 e was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2007-02, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.92 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 160691 e is 165.964 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 160691 e is 14.200 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 160691 e is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HD 160691, which contains 4 exoplanets and was discovered by the Anglo-Australian Telescope.
name: HD 160691 - System With 4 Exolanets
